CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 8;Not necessary to examine Art. 14+8;No violation of Art. 5-1;Not necessary to examine Art. 5-4;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award
TEXT: CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . The first applicant is PERSON , born in DATE . The second applicant is her daughter , PERSON , born in DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicants are of NORP origin . The first applicant was born in GPE into the family of a military officer of ORG ( GPE ) . At DATE she moved to GPE together with her parents . Her husband , PERSON , born in DATE , was transferred to GPE in DATE to serve as a NORP military officer . He met the first applicant in GPE and married her there in DATE . In DATE the first applicant gave birth to their daughter , the second applicant . The first applicant 's father retired from the army in DATE .
CARDINAL . GPE regained independence from the GPE in DATE . On DATE GPE assumed jurisdiction over the former NORP armed forces , including those stationed in the territory of GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants and the first applicant 's parents were entered in the register of NORP residents ( “ the register ” ) as “ ex - GPE citizens ” ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) . At that time , none of them were citizens of any particular ORG . In her request to be entered in the register , the first applicant had not indicated that her husband was a NORP military officer .

CARDINAL . The respondent Government state that , in requesting her entry in the register , the first applicant submitted false information about the occupation of PERSON , stating that he worked at a factory . The respondent Government have submitted a copy of an annex to the first applicant 's application for residence in GPE , including the statement that her husband worked at a factory .

CARDINAL . The applicants and the third party submit that the document is falsified , and that it does not exist . They also refer to the fact that , during the subsequent proceedings concerning the legality of their stay in GPE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) , the immigration authorities did not refer to any such false information , and the NORP courts did not establish that the applicants had at any point submitted the information mentioned by the respondent Government .

CARDINAL . PERSON , who had become a NORP citizen on an unspecified date in DATE , continued his service in the NORP army until his discharge in DATE on the ground of the abolition of his post . The parties disagree as to the actual date of his discharge : the applicants state that he was discharged on DATE . They rely on the fact that an order for his discharge was signed and became effective on DATE . The NORP Government support this conclusion . The respondent Government argue that the first applicant 's husband was discharged on DATE as it was only on that date that he formally completed his leave ; his leave allowance and retirement benefits had been calculated with reference to that date .
CARDINAL . The treaty between GPE and GPE on the withdrawal of the NORP troops ( “ the treaty ” ) was signed in GPE on DATE and became effective on that date ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . According to the respondent Government , even before the signature and entry into force of the treaty , various NORP and NORP authorities cooperated in establishing the names of the NORP military personnel liable to be removed from GPE . In this context , on DATE , the NORP military authorities submitted to the NORP authorities a list of the NORP military officers in GPE , including the first applicant 's husband , with an accompanying request to prolong his and his family 's temporary residence in GPE . This , the respondent Government contend , made it clear that their stay in GPE was temporary , and that they would be required to leave .

CARDINAL . According to the applicants and ORG , the list of DATE did not entail any obligation on PERSON to leave GPE as it was a document solely requesting the prolongation of his temporary stay in GPE , submitted before the actual signature and entry into force of the treaty .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON applied to ORG ( “ the CMA ” ) for a temporary residence permit in GPE by reason , inter alia , of his marriage to the first applicant , a permanent resident of GPE . This was refused on the ground that , as a NORP military officer , he was required to leave GPE as a result of the withdrawal of the NORP troops in accordance with the treaty .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG annulled the applicants ' entry in the register on the ground of PERSON military status . The applicants state that they were not informed about the decision , and that they found out about it only in DATE , in the context of the court proceedings brought by the first applicant 's husband ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . The respondent Government have also produced a list dated DATE , which according to them had been submitted to the NORP authorities by the NORP armed forces . In the list PERSON was included in the category of military personnel who had retired after DATE . The applicants and the third party contest the authenticity of the list .

CARDINAL . The respondent Government have further produced a list dated DATE , which according to them had been sent to ORG by the NORP consulate in GPE . According to the respondent Government , PERSON name appeared on the list among those NORP military pensioners who had been discharged from the NORP armed forces after DATE . It was also noted in the list that on QUANTITY DATE PERSON had been given housing in the city of Kursk in GPE , and that he had left GPE on DATE . The applicants and the third party contest the authenticity of the list .

CARDINAL . NORP In point of fact , however , the first applicant 's husband had stayed in GPE . He brought a court action against the GPE , claiming that their refusal to issue him with a temporary residence permit was void . On DATE FAC found in his favour . The ORG appealed against the judgment .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG allowed the ORG 's appeal , finding , inter alia , that PERSON had been a NORP military officer until DATE and that the treaty of DATE required all NORP officers in service on DATE to leave GPE together with their families . ORG referred , inter alia , to the list of DATE , which confirmed that he had been provided with accommodation in Kursk , and that he had left GPE in DATE . He did not bring a cassation appeal against the appellate judgment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the immigration authorities issued a deportation order in respect of the applicants . The order was served on them on DATE .

CARDINAL . On that date the local authorities decided to evict the applicants from their flat , which they rented from ORG . NORP military officers and their families as well as other residents of GPE lived in the block where the flat was located . The eviction order was not enforced .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date in DATE PERSON moved to GPE , while the applicants remained in GPE .

CARDINAL . The first applicant brought a court action in her own name and on behalf of her daughter , claiming that they were in fact permanent residents of GPE and that they could not be removed from the country .

CARDINAL . On DATE FAC found in favour of the applicants . The court held , inter alia , that the first applicant had come to GPE as a relative of her father , not her husband . As her father had retired in DATE , he could thereafter no longer be regarded as a military officer , and his close relatives , including the applicants , could be entered in the register as permanent residents of GPE . The court quashed the deportation order in respect of the applicants and authorised their re - entry in the register .

CARDINAL . The ORG appealed against the judgment of DATE . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal , finding that the first - instance court had decided the case properly . Upon a cassation appeal by the ORG , on DATE ORG quashed the decisions of the lower courts and remitted the case to the appellate court for a fresh examination . ORG referred to the fact that the applicants had been provided with a flat in Kursk , and that they were subject to the provisions of the treaty of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG allowed the ORG 's appeal , finding that PERSON had been a serving NORP military officer until DATE . Referring to the fact that he had been given housing in Kursk in DATE following his retirement from the NORP military , the court decided that he had been required to leave GPE with his family in accordance with the treaty . The court found that the decision of the immigration authorities to annul the applicants ' entry in the register had been lawful .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant was informed by the immigration authorities that the deportation order of DATE had become effective upon the delivery of the appellate court 's judgment of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , on a cassation appeal by the applicants , ORG confirmed the decision of CARDINAL DATE . ORG stated that PERSON had been discharged from the NORP armed forces on DATE . ORG noted that the applicants had been allocated the flat in Kursk in the context of the material assistance provided by GPE for the withdrawal of NORP troops . Relying on the fact that PERSON had been discharged from the military after DATE , ORG concluded that the applicants , as part of his family , had also been required to leave GPE in accordance with the treaty .
CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant requested the ORG to defer execution of the deportation order . That was refused on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant lodged with the immigration authorities an appeal against the deportation order , requesting a residence permit and her re - entry in the register . She stated , inter alia , that GPE was her and her daughter 's motherland as they had lived there all their lives and had no other citizenship , and that she was required to take care of her disabled parents who were permanently resident in GPE .

CARDINAL . In TIME of CARDINAL DATE the police entered the applicants ' flat . They were arrested at TIME on the same date . On DATE , at TIME , a police officer issued an arrest warrant in respect of the applicants on the basis of section CARDINAL of LAW . The warrant stated that the applicants had no valid documents justifying their stay in GPE , and that the applicants ' entry in the register of NORP residents had been annulled by ORG final judgment of CARDINAL DATE . It was also mentioned in the warrant that the applicants “ did not leave GPE following the judgment , and there were reasonable grounds to suspect that they were staying in GPE illegally ” . The warrant was signed by the applicants . On the basis of the warrant the applicants were immediately detained in a centre for illegal immigrants .

CARDINAL . Also on CARDINAL DATE the Director of the ORG sent a letter to the immigration police , stating that the applicants ' arrest had been “ premature ” in view of the fact that the first applicant had lodged an appeal on DATE . No reference to domestic law was made in the letter . The Director of the ORG ordered the immigration police to release the applicants . They were released at an unspecified time on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants received a letter from the Director of the ORG dated DATE , informing them that they were required to leave GPE immediately . They were also informed that , if they complied voluntarily with the deportation order , they could thereafter be issued with a visa enabling them to stay in the country for DATE per annum .

CARDINAL . On DATE the flat of the first applicant 's parents was searched by the police in the presence of the second applicant . On DATE , at TIME , a police officer issued a warrant for the second applicant 's arrest on the basis of section CARDINAL of LAW . The warrant stated that the second applicant had no valid document justifying her stay in GPE , and that there were reasonable grounds to suspect that she was staying in GPE illegally . The order was signed by the second applicant . She was immediately arrested and thereafter detained for TIME in a centre for illegal immigrants . She was released on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants moved to GPE to join PERSON . By that time the second applicant had completed her secondary education in GPE . On an unspecified date in DATE the applicants adopted NORP citizenship as former nationals of the GPE . The applicants now live in Kursk , in accommodation which was provided by the NORP defence authorities . After the applicants left GPE , their flat in GPE was taken back by the NORP authorities . Meanwhile , the first applicant 's parents continued living in GPE on the basis of their status as “ ex - GPE citizens ” .

CARDINAL . According to the applicants , the first applicant 's parents are seriously ill , but the applicants have not been able to go to GPE to visit them . The deportation order of CARDINAL DATE prohibited the applicants from entering GPE for DATE . That prohibition expired on DATE . Towards DATE the applicants obtained visas permitting their stay in GPE for DATE per annum .
CARDINAL . In view of the fact that PERSON had left GPE voluntarily , the prohibition on entering GPE was not extended to him . He was allowed to visit GPE several times in the period DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP laws use the term “ citizenship ” ( pilsonība ) to denote the nationality of a person . In the official LANGUAGE translations of the domestic statutes , the term “ nationality ” is sometimes used in brackets alongside the term “ citizenship ” . An official LANGUAGE translation of LAW ( Part I ) provides , for example , that “ an ' alien ' [ is ] a person having the citizenship ( nationality ) of another ORG ; [ a ] ' stateless person ' [ is ] a person having no citizenship ( nationality ) ” .
CARDINAL . NORP legislation on nationality and immigration identifies several categories of persons , each with its own status defined in a specific Act :
( a ) NORP citizens ( Latvijas Republikas pilsoņi ) , whose legal status is governed by LAW of DATE ( ORG likums ) ;

( b ) “ permanently resident non - citizens ” ( nepilsoņi ) – that is , citizens of the former GPE who lost their NORP citizenship following the dissolution of the GPE but have not subsequently obtained any other nationality DATE who are governed by the Status of Former GPE LAW of DATE ( NORP “ PERSON to bijušo ORG pilsoņu statusu , kuriem nav Latvijas vai citas valsts pilsonības ” ) ; this group of persons may also be referred to as “ ex - GPE citizens ” ;
( c ) asylum - seekers and refugees , whose status is governed by LAW ( Patvēruma likums ) ;

( d ) “ stateless persons ” ( bezvalstnieki ) within the meaning of LAW of DATE ( NORP “ ORG bezvalstnieka statusu Latvijas NORP ” ) , read in conjunction with LAW and , since DATE , with LAW which replaced it ;

( e ) “ aliens ” in the broad sense of the term ( ārzemnieki ) , including foreign nationals ( ārvalstnieki ) and stateless persons ( bezvalstnieki ) falling solely within the ambit of the Aliens and Stateless Persons ( Entry and Residence ) Act of DATE ( NORP “ ORG ārvalstnieku un bezvalstnieku ieceļošanu un uzturēšanos GPE DATE – “ LAW ” ) ( before DATE ) , and LAW ( after DATE ) .

CARDINAL . LAW is based on CARDINAL principles : the principle of jus sanguinis and the doctrine of ORG succession in matters of international and constitutional law . Accordingly , with certain exceptions , only those persons who had NORP citizenship on DATE ( the date on which GPE came under NORP domination ) and their descendants are recognised ipso jure as NORP citizens ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . The fact of having been born within NORP territory or having been resident there for DATE does not in itself confer NORP citizenship ; accordingly , citizens of the former GPE who arrived in GPE during the NORP era ( DATE ) and their descendants were not automatically granted NORP citizenship after GPE had regained its independence .

CARDINAL . Furthermore , LAW provides for the possibility of becoming a NORP citizen by means of naturalisation , in accordance with the conditions and procedure laid down in LAW of the LAW . Persons seeking naturalisation as NORP citizens must have been lawfully resident in GPE for at least DATE , have a legal source of income , pass an examination testing proficiency in NORP , be familiar with LAW and national anthem , have a basic knowledge of NORP history , swear an oath of allegiance and , where appropriate , renounce their existing citizenship ( section CARDINAL ) . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) lists the grounds on which naturalisation may be refused ; for example the provision prohibits the naturalisation of persons who

“ ... after DATE chose GPE as their place of residence immediately after being discharged from the GPE ( NORP ) armed forces , and who did not have their permanent residence in GPE on the date of their conscription or enlistment ... ” .
CARDINAL . In the version in force before DATE , section CARDINAL of the Status of Former GPE LAW provided :

“ ( CARDINAL ) This Act shall apply to citizens of the former GPE who are resident in GPE ... , were resident within NORP territory before DATE and are registered as being resident there , regardless of the status of their housing , provided that they are not citizens of GPE or of any other ORG , and also to their children below the age of majority , if the latter are not citizens of GPE or of any other ORG . ”
In the version in force since DATE , section CARDINAL of the Status of Former GPE LAW provides :
“ ( CARDINAL ) The persons governed by LAW non - citizens ' – shall be those citizens of the former GPE , and their children , who are resident in GPE ... and who satisfy all the following criteria :

CARDINAL . NORP on DATE they were registered as being resident within the territory of GPE , regardless of the status of their housing ; or their last registered place of residence by DATE was in GPE ; or a court has established that before the above - mentioned date they had been resident within the territory of GPE for not less than DATE ;
CARDINAL . NORP they do not have NORP citizenship ; and
CARDINAL . NORP they are not and have not been citizens of any other ORG .
( CARDINAL ) NORP The legal status of persons who arrived in GPE after DATE shall be determined by the ORG and ORG .
( CARDINAL ) The present Act shall not apply to :
CARDINAL . NORP military specialists engaged in the operation and dismantling of GPE military [ radar equipment ] installed in the territory of GPE , and civilians sent to GPE for that purpose ;

CARDINAL . NORP persons who were discharged from the armed forces after DATE , if on the date of their enlistment they were not permanently resident in the territory of GPE and if they are not close relatives of NORP citizens ;

CARDINAL . NORP spouses of the persons [ mentioned above ] and members of their families ( children and other dependants ) living with them , where , irrespective of the date of their arrival , they arrived in GPE in connection with the service of a member of GPE ( GPE ) armed forces ;

CARDINAL . NORP persons who have received compensation for establishing their permanent residence abroad , regardless of whether the compensation was paid by a NORP central or local authority or by an international or foreign authority or foundation ; or
CARDINAL . NORP persons who on DATE were officially registered as being resident for an indefinite period within a member country of ORG . ”

Section CARDINAL ( ) CARDINAL of the LAW prohibits the deportation of “ non - citizens ” , “ save where deportation takes place in accordance with the law and another ORG has agreed to receive the deportee ” . Furthermore , section CARDINAL ( which became section CARDINAL on DATE ) provides :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Section CARDINAL ... of this LAW shall also [ apply to ] stateless persons and their descendants who are not and have never been citizens of any ORG and who , before DATE , were resident within the territory of GPE and were registered as being permanently resident there ...

( CARDINAL ) Section CARDINAL of this Act shall also apply to nationals of other GPE and their descendants who were resident within the territory of GPE before DATE and were registered as being permanently resident there ... , provided that they do not have NORP citizenship ... ”
Lastly , section DATE provides that international agreements on immigration “ concluded by GPE and approved by ORG ” take precedence over national legislation .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW were worded as follows :
Section CARDINAL

“ Any foreigner or stateless person shall be entitled to stay in GPE for DATE [ version in force from CARDINAL DATE : ' DATE in the course of CARDINAL of a calendar DATE ' ] , provided that he or she has obtained a residence permit in accordance with the provisions of this Act . ... ”
Section CARDINAL
“ The following may obtain a permanent residence permit :

( CARDINAL ) the spouse of a NORP citizen , of a ' permanently resident non - citizen ' of GPE or of an alien or stateless person who has [ himself or herself ] been granted a permanent residence permit , in accordance [ with section ] ... CARDINAL of this LAW , and the spouse 's minor or dependent children ... ”

CARDINAL . When LAW came into force , it did not contain any provision excluding serving members of the NORP armed forces who had been discharged after DATE . Regulation no . CARDINAL of DATE , confirmed by LAW of DATE , amended section CARDINAL as follows :

“ Permanent residence permits may be obtained by aliens who , on DATE , were officially registered as being resident for an indefinite period within GPE if , at the time of applying for a permanent residence permit , they are officially registered as being resident within GPE and are entered in the register of residents .

Citizens of the former GPE who acquired the citizenship of another ORG DATE must apply for a permanent residence permit by DATE . ORG of the former GPE who acquired the citizenship of another ORG after DATE must apply within DATE on which they acquired the citizenship of that ORG .
This section shall not apply to :
CARDINAL . NORP military specialists engaged in the operation and dismantling of NORP military [ radar equipment ] installed in the territory of GPE , and civilians sent to GPE for that purpose ;

CARDINAL . NORP persons who were discharged from active military service after DATE if on the date of their enlistment they were not permanently resident in the territory of GPE and if they are not close relatives of NORP citizens ; or

CARDINAL . NORP spouses of the persons [ mentioned above ] and members of their families ( children and other dependants ) living with them , where , irrespective of the date of their arrival , they arrived in GPE in connection with the service of a member of GPE ( GPE ) armed forces . ”

CARDINAL . Persons who are lawfully resident in GPE are entered in the register of residents and given a personal identification number ( personas kods ) . The functioning of the register , which is kept by the interior authorities , is laid down in LAW of DATE ( ORG reģistra likums ) , which replaced LAW of DATE ( Likums “ ORG iedzīvotāju reģistru ” ) .

CARDINAL . According to the information provided by the respondent Government , CARDINAL persons DATE close relatives of NORP military officers required to leave GPE under the treaty – were able to legalise their stay in GPE because those persons were either NORP citizens or close relatives of NORP citizens , and had not arrived in GPE in connection with service in the NORP armed forces .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW lists the circumstances in which a residence permit , even a temporary one , will not be issued . LAW lists the grounds on which a residence permit may be withdrawn . The fact of having been a serving member of the NORP armed forces after DATE does not appear in either of these lists .

Point CARDINAL of section DATE provides that a residence permit should be withdrawn where its holder “ has knowingly submitted false information to the GPE ” . Point CARDINAL provides for the same consequences if the holder of a residence permit “ arouses reasonable suspicion on the part of the competent authorities that he or she presents a threat to public order and safety or national security ” . Point CARDINAL concerns persons who have “ entered the service of a foreign ORG , whether in the armed forces or otherwise , except in cases provided for by international agreements ” . Lastly , point CARDINAL concerns persons who have “ received compensation for establishing their permanent residence abroad , regardless of whether the compensation was paid by a NORP central or local authority or by an international or foreign authority or foundation ” .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the LAW provides that the head of ORG or of one of its regional offices should issue a deportation order where an alien or stateless person resides within the territory of GPE without being in possession of a valid visa or residence permit or in any other circumstances listed in DATE .
CARDINAL . Sections DATE and CARDINAL provide :

“ Where a deportation order is issued in respect of a person with dependent relatives in GPE , the latter must leave with him or her . The deportation order shall not apply to members of his or her family who are NORP citizens or non - citizens . ”

“ A person shall leave the territory of GPE within DATE after the deportation order has been served on him or her , provided that no appeal is lodged against the order in the manner prescribed in this section .
Persons in respect of whom a deportation order is issued may appeal against it within DATE to the head of the ORG , who shall extend the residence permit pending consideration of the appeal .

An appeal against the decision of the head of the GPE shall lie to the court within whose territorial jurisdiction the ORG 's headquarters are situated , within DATE after the decision has been served . ”

CARDINAL . Under LAW , where a person has not complied with a deportation order , he or she may be forcefully removed from GPE by the police . Under section DATE , the police have the right to arrest a person in order to execute a deportation order .
Under section DATE , the police have the right to arrest a person where no decision to deport him or her has been taken , if :
( CARDINAL ) the person has illegally entered the ORG ;
( CARDINAL ) NORP the person has knowingly provided false information to the competent authorities in order to receive a visa or residence permit ;
( CARDINAL ) the authorities have a well - founded suspicion that the person will hide , or that he or she has no permanent place of residence ; or
( CARDINAL ) the authorities have a well - founded suspicion that the person poses a threat to public order or national security .

In such cases the police have the right to detain a person for not more than TIME , or , where a prosecutor has been notified , for not more than ten days . The police must immediately inform the immigration authorities about the arrest , with a view to their issuing an order for the deportation of the person by the use of force . The person concerned can appeal against that deportation order in accordance with the provisions of section QUANTITY .

By section CARDINAL - CARDINAL , a person in respect of whom such a deportation order has been issued may be detained until the execution of the order , and a prosecutor must be notified of the order .
Section DATE provides that an arrested person must be immediately informed of the reasons for his arrest , and of his right to have legal assistance .

By section CARDINAL - CARDINAL , the police have the right to arrest aliens and stateless persons who reside in GPE without a valid visa or residence permit . Such persons must be brought to the immigration authorities or to a police remand centre within TIME .
CARDINAL . Chapter CARDINAL-A of the Code of Civil Procedure guarantees the right to appeal to a court against administrative acts breaching personal rights .

Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL states that a complaint against an action ( decision ) of a ORG authority may be submitted to a court , after a hierarchical complaint in this connection has been determined by the competent administrative authority .

Under LAW - CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW , a complaint to a court may be submitted within DATE from the date of the notification of the dismissal of the hierarchical complaint , or within DATE from DATE of the contested act , provided that the person concerned has not received a decision .
Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL provides that the court must examine the complaint within DATE , having questioned the parties and other persons , if necessary .
Pursuant to LAW , if the court considers that the act concerned violates an individual 's personal rights , the court should adopt a judgment obliging the authority to remedy the violation .

CARDINAL . Under the NORP legislation , a citizen was issued with a “ registration ” ( propiska ) at a particular address , by way of a special seal in his passport attesting to his place of permanent residence for the purposes of domestic law . Following the restoration of NORP independence in DATE , the “ registration ” system remained effective under the NORP legislation .

CARDINAL . The treaty between GPE and GPE on the conditions and schedule for the complete withdrawal of GPE military troops from the territory of GPE and their status pending withdrawal ( “ the treaty ” ) was signed in GPE on DATE , published in GPE ( Official Gazette ) on DATE , and came into force on DATE .
In the preamble of the treaty the parties stated , inter alia , that by signing the treaty they wished to “ eradicate the negative consequences of their common history ” .
CARDINAL . The other relevant provisions of the treaty read as follows :
“ GPE military troops shall leave the territory of GPE by DATE .
The withdrawal of GPE military troops shall concern all members of the armed forces of GPE , members of their families and their movable property .
The closure of military bases in the territory of GPE and the discharge of military personnel after DATE shall not be regarded as the withdrawal of military troops .

“ The GPE shall inform GPE about its military personnel and their families in the territory of GPE . It shall provide regular information , DATE , about the withdrawal of , and quantitative changes in , each of the above - mentioned groups . ... ”

“ GPE shall guarantee the rights and freedoms of GPE military troops affected by the withdrawal , and also of their families , in accordance with the legislation of GPE and the principles of international law . ”
“ This treaty ... shall be applied on a provisional basis from the date of signature and shall come into force on the date of exchange of the instruments of ratification . ... ”

CARDINAL . The conditions for the implementation by GPE of the above - mentioned treaty are laid down in Regulation no . CARDINAL of DATE , the relevant parts of the second paragraph of which provide :
“ ORG :

CARDINAL . shall issue residence permits , after checking the list of military personnel ... to discharged members of the NORP armed forces who were resident within the territory of GPE on DATE and have been registered by ORG ...
CARDINAL . NORP shall issue deportation orders in respect of members of the armed forces who are unlawfully resident in GPE , and shall supervise the execution of such orders ; ... ”

CARDINAL . An agreement between GPE and GPE , also signed on DATE , concerns the social protection of retired members of ORG armed forces and their families residing within the territory of GPE . LAW , which applies principally to persons discharged from the NORP armed forces before GPE regained its independence , provides :

“ The persons to whom this agreement applies shall enjoy their fundamental rights within the territory of GPE , in accordance with the standards of international law , the provisions of this agreement and NORP legislation .

The persons to whom this agreement applies ... and who were permanently resident within the territory of GPE before DATE , including those in respect of whom the relevant formalities have not been carried out and who are on the lists verified by both parties and appended to this agreement , shall retain the right to reside without hindrance in the territory of GPE , if they so desire . By agreement between the Parties , any persons who were permanently resident within the territory of GPE before DATE and , for various reasons , have not been included on the lists referred to above may be added to them . ... ”
